title: Raspberry pi 2 basic case Remix to mount on ACER V193W monitor

description.text:
9/8/2017 Update
I needed this mount to have a little narrower mount hole spacing for the electronics case I am working on & made a version for 88x72mm spacing instead of the 100mm. While working on this I found a couple of small problems to fix in the previous design, most notably the plastic mount for the raspberry pi were a little small & tended to break easy. I changed those from 2mm to 2.5mm. The narrower mount version is MonitorMountBottom_88x72Mnt_rev9.stl. This is Modification of Raspberry Pi Case http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:692568 to mount to the back of an ACER V193W monitor I used 4 - M4x16mm socket screws to mount to monitor
4 - M3x16mm socket screws to attach bottom & Top Case together
4 - M3 Jam nuts
I used this HDMI Male to VGA Female Video Converter Adapter Cable.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00C0Y6BQG/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

A Moineau pump is a type of positive displacement pump with steady flow (no pulsing).  This type of pump is common in the food processing industry because it can efficiently pump slurries (like soup) without crushing the contents.  This one pumps 32 cc/revolution (neglecting whatever leaks back through the seals) and is capable of pumping water (milk is shown for contrast).  
I thought this might be useful as a paste extruder or something of that nature.  It's better than a peristaltic pump because no flexible hose is needed (which tend to reduce efficiency and wear out), plus it doesn't pulse.

Print out one of each part except the gap.  The gap isn't printable, it's just there to model the shape of the internal cavities between the rotor and stator so you can visualize how each compartment moves upward while staying sealed away from the others at all times.  One whole compartment is visible, along with portions of three others.
The rotor slides down into the stator; it's a tight fit, but that helps it seal.  Once it's lubricated by whatever you're pumping, it'll go easier.  The crank twists onto the rotor; no need for glue.  It'll stay tight as long as you're pumping the right way (fluid moving toward the crank), but it'll fall off if you turn it backwards.
No need to prime the pump, just submerge the base in fluid and crank away.  
A parametric OpenSCAD file is included so you can change the parameters to suit your needs.  It will display the pumping rate based on your choices.  You can also change the tolerance, though I found it works fine with zero, just relying on the flexibility of the plastic.  I also made the wall thickness exactly two tread-widths wide, so the dimensions would be accurate.  You may want to change this for your printer.
UPDATE: Thanks to Proton for making an animated version of the OpenSCAD file.  This version is now included, so you can control the animation for yourself.

comments.text:
It is the basic design , the way a progressive cavity pump works.
The core of the stator needs to be a heavy elastomer , such as (Alumilite High Strength 3 RTV silicone).
With out a flexible inner core the rotor will not seal. If you would like , I can take a pic of a core ant the building mold used to make it.

comments.text: Could someone please make the stator thicker like 5mm. I know there is a openscad file but i don't really understand what I would change.
comments.author: jonny

comments.text: i would not recommend it. for the pump the be able to move and maintain a seal, either the rotor or the stator needs to be able to deform a little. with 'real' pumps, they use rubber, but since we're using hard plastic, a thin wall will have to do.
comments.author: jonny

comments.text: In commercial pumps they use two main methods to hook up the motor; a double U-joint (cardan joint) or a slim flexible shaft.  I bet you could punch a hole part way down the rotor and run a skinny shaft up it, sticking out a ways.  The shaft needs to be torsionally stiff, but flexible side to side.  It needs to have some length to it to allow the side to side motion of the rotor.

title: Simple Prusa i3 (hephestos) mount for Airtripper's Bowden Extruder

description.text:
My first try at creating something useful for my Prusa i3 hephestos. A mount for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:126778 that fits on the top portion of the frame... I've also added the .SCAD file for customizing.
Oh yes, you'll need the "Nut's and Bolts" Lib installed, wich you can find here:
https://github.com/JohK/nutsnbolts

Printed in PLA with 0.2mm layer-thickness and 30% infill. You'll need the following things to attach Airtripper's extruder:
  • 2 M4x12mm screws
  • 4 M4 washers
  • 2 M4 nuts
    • Just fix the extruder to the mounting base (I had to file the holes a little bit) and attach everyting to the top of the frame. That's it. On the printer you should replace your 'default' M3 screws by some longer ones.

title: The 3D Printed Marble Machine #2

description.text:
The 3D Printed Marble Machine #2 - Designed by Tulio Laanen
Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4uJugZ2lUi4

  • Please consider making a donation if you want to support me and my work.
    Donate HERE: http://bit.ly/1GovCl0

  • Check out; The 3D Printed Marble Machine #3 !
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1385312

  • Check out my first 3D Printed Marble Machine as well:
    Thingiverse: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:615203
    Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0wrA-zyLiBg

  • Contact mail: [email protected]
  • My website: http://www.tuliolaanen.com
    • Made one yourself? Feel free to upload your photo’s!

Its very simple!

  • I recommend slicing with with Cura: https://ultimaker.com/en/software/list

  • Optimal settings:
    Layer height: 0.1 (0.2 optional for faster print)
    Shell thickness: 0.8
    Bottom/Top thickness: 0.6
    Fill Density: 25%
    Print speed: 40 mm/s
    No Support, brim or raft needed.

  • use 9.5 - 10mm ball-bearings for Marbles

  • And print!
    • (I Printed on Ultimaker 2)
    .
    .
    Explanation different download files:

  • R_The_3D_Marble_Machine_2_Final_Model.stl
    Original file. Works the best with given instructions above, which means slicing with Cura.

  • repaird version:
    Fixed version, if your not using cura, or if you're experiencing problems while slicing.

  • The four parts in separate STL files:
    Cap, Turning wheel, Lift, Track

  • and there is a version of the lift (spiral) without the support cilinder around it if you prefer to print it with a brim or a raft

comments.text: hi Tulio, I think one improvement that can be made to the design is the little section where the ramp ends. With 9.5mm bearings, I find that often, the bearing doesn't quite go into the area of the elevator where it will get picked up by the shaft, or even worse, the bearing can get stuck on the left side of the elevator entrance and then the next bearing comes, and the two of them block the entrance to the elevator and then the whole thing stops and you have to pull out all the bearings.  I think if the end of the ramp extends a bit further towards the elevator entrance should fix this problem.  What do you think?

comments.text:
I did a new version of the lift screw and turning blade. Since the original stl files prevented openscad from rendering when imported I remade em with primitives. Printing now to verify my design before posting a remix.
The combined screw and turningblade pops into a modified top cap that has been opened to allow screw and blade to just slide in. The benefit of the combined turningblade and screw is the screw can be printed with the hole facing up (and eventually hole can be replaced by peg or even screw through the baseplate) and the turningblade makes for better bed adhesion. No hardcoded skirt also allows proper brim to be generated if needed. Skirt can always be generated in slicer app.

comments.text:
Nice that you made it work for you!. While designing I've really thought a lot about it and I concidered your idea as -well, but there where several reasons why i went for the separate parts. I explained one reason in an previous comment: "While designing, I've tried different setups, and after a lot of trail and error I figured that it works the best in separate parts. Mostly because it turns way more smoothly like this. I noticed that the bottom-surface that sticks to the bottom-plate while printing an object, always ends up with the smoothest texture. So when printing it is separate parts it takes advantage of that fact, because the cap turns on top of the smooth side of the turning wheel.
And on top of that, I think its just way more fun this way! "
.
But I have definitely seen some points of improvement. In the next marble machine I am going to make some changes to improve it.
I have my reasons why I made it the way it is, and why I don't want to use screws, brims or rafts for example. (You can read a bit about it on: http://3dprint.com/62151/3d-printed-marble-machine-2/ )
comments.author: KreAture

comments.text:
This is an awsome design and I am also giggling like a schoolboy playing with it.
The trick to smooth rotation is accomplished in my remix by making the screw a tiny bit too short to reach the bottom. It is thus centered by the peg but rides 0.1-0.2mm abowe the base so the triangle does not catch. One way to secure this is to make the absolute bottom(top when printing) of the screw a rounded piece about 0.3mm high. This would integrate a washer in the design.
On the other end where I have now fed it through a larger hole it is rotating very smoothly as the new spiral is rotating ontop of the bottom of the cap. The cap was against the glass bed when printed so is very smooth. Again I could have implemented a small ring to reduce the contact area but it dpes not appear to be necessary. I printed my entire machine in PLA since there is no heatsources involved and I didn't want to fiddle with warping. PLA has less friction against itself than ABS has against itself.
comments.author: Tulio

comments.text:
I used Slic3r 1.2.6 (experimental) and printed on my homemade Rostock Plus (A modified, scaled up version of the original Rostock but with a lot of small changes and some major like stiffening via crossbracing.)
The track+screw took 15 hours when I set it to print slow to avoid any head collisions. (I use a very narrow/pointy nozzle so it easily collides on curled up overhangs etc.) I printed in black PLA.

remixed_from.author: scratchhax
remixed_from.title: i3v anti z wobble and backlash mount

title: i3v anti z wobble and backlash mount Remix for easier printing & variable configurations

description.text:
This is a Remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:769057 modification which was a remix of Scratchhax's Thing at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:766440
This remix does the following.
  • to make it printable without support (used 45 degree incline)
  • Made it 1mm wider for nut hole vertex not hitting inside edge
  • Parametric openscad file to vary dimensions for Spring & T-nut mounting height
  • You can also print this without the spring to just give you more x travel distance
    I attached several stl files to show you the various options.
    • I have not put this part into service on my printer yet, but did check it for fitting.
    If you use the openscad file, the variables you may want to change are: Tht=1.6; //Originally was 2.5 without 45 taper (tnut Height)
    //I used 1.3mm on the 1st version, but was too tight, 1.6mm worked well on rev4 version
    Nuts=2; //1 or 2 Nuts, no spring needed with 1 nut
    Spring=1; //0 = No Spring, 1 = Spring
    SpringLen=50; //Based on original using 30mm for 50mm spring
    // I use 3/5 scale factor for the Spring window To test for fit on your machine, I would print this part:
    Z-Axis_AntiBackLashMod_2x_NoSpring_1Nut_1_6mmTnutHt_rev4_repaired.stl
    I find printing 2 parts at a time will give me a better print since it helps my printing for it to dry a little longer between heights. The "Tht" variable you may want to adjust for the fit you like. I saw that Lowes has a 38mm length spring that may work for this, which is why I gave this a variable. I am planning to use this without a spring to start with to get the extra X travel distance Update Rev4 Upldated 6/8/2015
    After installing my plastic version of the X-motor Mount & X-Idler plate I noticed this did not fit around my added ledge on the outside & had to use the dremel to cut the top at a 45 to make it fit. Normally, I would have just printed this modified version, but my printer was apart at this point. I adjusted the height of the tmount connection so it is a slip fit. I had to file the previous version down a little to get it to fit.

remixed_from.author: QuentinT
remixed_from.title: Improved! iPhone Gear Case with Geneva Mechanism

title: iPhone 5 Gear Case with Geneva Mechanism

description.text: This case was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:65810 which is a fantastic gear case by QuentinT. I wanted an iPhone 5 version, as well as the challenge of designing one. In an homage to QuentinT's version I kept the look very similar, since it was already so fantastic and laid out so efficiently. This version also features a soft spring loaded power switch which gives good feedback when clicked.

Update added "deeper" version of the phone case, print whichever version you prefer

  • Print out one of each part except for the pins.
    You will need 3 of 4.5x5 pins
    and 3 of 4.5x6.5 pins
    and 1 of 6.5x6.5 pins

  • Sand all the gear faces and surfaces really well. I have included a "Fit Tester" that let me check how the gears were meshing.

  • SuperGlue the Ridge onto the back of the case. Line it up as best as you can.

  • Drill out the holes and attach the gears using the pins. 6.5mm diameter for the main gear.
    use the shorter 4.5mm diameter pins for gears that are in the "lower layer"
    and use the longer remaining pins for gears that rest in the "upper layer" or are thicker such as the 35 tooth geneva gear

  • On the Power button, use some superglue on the flat spot opposite of the actual button part. Glue it into the top of the shell so the button protrudes out of the case slightly.
    • The gears made using my printer needed a bit of break-in. To make that go a bit faster I have also included a gear chuck. Which pops onto the main gear and allows you more leverage when hand turning it. Also it has a hex hole so I could use an electric screwdriver to turn it for me. This case held onto my phone so solidly that it was a bit hard to get it out the first time. I sanded the inside edges a bit more and now I have a nice secure fit that still pops out when I want without much fuss. Enjoy, and Thanks Again to QuentinT

remixed_from.author: adafruit
remixed_from.title: Adafruit Pi Box - Enclosure for Raspberry PiÂ® Computers

description.text: It's basically CongoJoe's stacking case modified for the Raspberry Pi 2. I needed one for my new Pi 2, and I like his simple yet functional stacking  mod for the original Adafruit Pi Box. I've added some breakaway slots on top for easier access to the GPIO, screen and camera contacts. There's not much material around the GPIO slot, so be careful if you decide to use it. Or redesign the whole thing. Putting the slots in the sides of the case would eliminate the problem and make stacking cases with cameras or screens or other I/Os possible. Use 3mm thick material, like the acrylic in the pics, for a snug fit.

This was laser cut from a 3 mm acrylic sheet. The slots and snap locks have been carefully adjusted through trial and error to fit this material. (Tip of the hat to my friend Fredric for patiently and repeatedly adjusting stuff on the go by the laser cutter.) The Pi itself can be fastened with screws to the base of the case. This isn't really necessary, as the fit proved to be quite snug as it is. Take care to mount the short end with the slot for the micro SD card the right way. The card sits slightly off centre on the Pi 2. The breakaway slots for the GPIO and other contacts haven't been tested, and I think the GPIO slot looks particularly flimsy, so be careful if you decide to use it.

comments.text: I wish there was a way, other than gravity, to make the stack hold together better. I've found with the older case that with USB cables, power, and such, things don't always stack well.
comments.author: albill

comments.text: Excellent point. I suppose it's possible to hack it by copying the very clever snap locks (which sadly isn't my design) and place a few of them vertically next to the semi circular bits that holds them in place on the original design, with corresponding slots at the other end. Or use straps, but that kind of ruins the neat look. Unless you find some very sleek straps. I might just have a go at the snap lock variety when I have the time. (You're welcome to try if you have the tools. :)) You've given me a brilliant idea. Thanks!

comments.author: jjohnson5253

comments.text: This box was made for laser cutting. There are no STL files for the pieces. If you wish to 3D print it, you may import the drawings into a 3D software program like Sketchup and use a tool (like the "Push/pull" tool in Sketchup) to extrude the surfaces to 3 mm. Depending on the X,Y and Z tolerances of your 3D printer, you'll end up with pieces that may or may not fit snugly together. I think there are better Pi cases out there that are specifically designed for 3D printing, to be honest.

description.text: You'll need the original Cryptex files from pbloom's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7233 The OpenSCAD file can be used to generate any of the 36 letters or numbers on the cryptex. The OpenSCAD file works by splitting the interior and exterior into separate pieces, rotating the exterior until it aligns the notch with a new letter, and then joins the two pieces back. Also, it appeared that the original STL was saved in inches, rather than mm, so I scaled the file up by a factor of 25.4. As an example, although pbloom only uploaded the letters "DEC14", I've included the ring for the letter "Z" made with this OpenSCAD file. I've also included a key of how much the outer ring should be rotated to match with each letter and number.

• Use the legend in the OpenSCAD file to get the letter you want
  • Export desired letter/ring combination

description.text:
Not the connection Ball, but the same idea. Without the seat part (stil in progress) you can construct a chair.
The idea was to show a chair with a net made out of 20mm x 20mm square bars, which hung in between a frame. but since I had overwritten a file while exporting seperate STL file I lost everything and this was the stuff that could be saved. But hey it was my own mouse click. :-/ Unfortunately the file could not be recovered. I hate the end result, but maybe you like it... This is a work in progress that I will continue in the year 2034. TIP:
This print costed me 7 years of my life :-/ So.... Always save your complete stuff file on a removable disk and place it somewhere under a rock in your garden as a backup untill you are finished. If you don't own a garden somewhere in a closet will do. Just NEVER trust it into your own hands until you are finished.

title: Macbook Pro Power Cord Repair Strain Relief

description.text: This is a replacement part for the cord strain relief on an Apple macbook power adapter. Useful if you've decided to repair a severed magsafe cord by opening the adapter and resoldering the severed cord. If your cord is not severed and you just want to prevent this from happening, you should use one of the other available designs, like these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:154463 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:141012

A number of guides for doing the actual repair are available here: https://www.ifixit.com/Device/Apple_AC_Adapter Just print 2 of these and assemble in place of the hot glue recommended in many of the repair guides. A small zip tie is used in the groove on the end to hold things together.

Stands for Clamp for Handrail with Additively Manufactured Parts. Originally designed for a NASA competition, but it can be repurposed by changing the size of the hole. Stress testing with ABS plastic showed that it can hold over 50 lbs.
Liquid Stand for Standart 10ml Bottles

Print in 100% for 10ml bottles. 120mm x 48mm x 41mm.
Print in 148% for 30ml bottles. 178mm x 71mm x 61mm.
Hole diameter 10ml 21mm.
Hole diameter 30ml 31mm.
The bottles fits tight.
If you want more space, just print a few % bigger.

Materials: 1 Sheet 2'x4' 1/2" MDF
1 Box 1" 1/4-20 Set Screws
1 Box 1/4-20 Lock Nuts Tools:
I'm using a CNC with a 25"x25" table, thus the 2 2'x2' sheets.
1/4" Endmill Wooden train tracks, compatible with most commercial tracks and toy trains. Cut from 1/2" MDF. Create toolpaths from the attached DXF files. Cut the profile 1/2" deep, and cut center on the track line 1/8" deep, all using a 1/4" endmill. Connectors can be made from MDF (might break, but I have some drawn in anyways) or from common hardware. I used 1" 1/4-20 set screws with lock nuts which slide in perfectly and hold them as securely as other systems do. Those with 3D printers may want to try: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15165 Careful when cutting using MDF, the ridges can rip easily on the CNC, but they seem to be standing up to normal play.

description.text:
O-SD stands for Old (or Original, if you prefer) Super Deformed. It is based on first SD kits released by Bandai (G-generation Zero / G-generation F). They are shorter, more stubby and usually without legs. Automatic support is needed; the model is simple and easy to build with plenty of detail carved in. A bit of sanding is required for a more polished result, after some paint I´m sure it will blend well in your gunpla collection. All pieces are available with and without built-in supports. This kit includes:
  • MA-M3 Heavy Sword
  • MMI-M8A3 76mm Heavy Assault Machine Gun
  • Elijah Kiel Custom "Buster Sword" head fin
  • New waist model with new slots to store the sword
    • Follow the latest developments here:
    https://noedgesite.wordpress.com If you like what I’am doing and want to see more please support on patreon:
    https://www.patreon.com/Noedge

description.text:
3D Designed and 3D Printed a low poly hat for all us 3D printing nerds out there! I'm a hat freak and being able to 3D print a hat is crazy cool. This model will prepare into makerbot desktop around: 193mm (ear to ear) x 248mm (foreHead to back) x 122mm (tall)
My head is pretty large so should work on most medium sized printers if you print the hat in two parts. TimeLapse Video - Printing without Supports:
https://youtu.be/BLVXMMoCT-0 Happy 3D Printing! Feel free to follow me at:
http://www.Youtube.com/PrintThatThing
http://instagram.com/printthatthing
https://twitter.com/PRINTTHATTHING

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/BLVXMMoCT-0" ></iframe>
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/wy8mUDsJqOA" ></iframe>

I printed this hat on a MakerBot Replicator 5th Gen in two parts. The "CAP" & "BRIM" CAP:
.2 mm Layers
NO Supports
Rafts "ON"
2 shells UPDATE: Added a file "myVYBES_CAP_wSUPPORTS_fixed" that has supports built in. Print the same as above then remove the build in supports when done. BRIM:
.2mm Layers
NO Supports
Rafts "ON"
2 shells Once printed I glued the CAP & BRIM together using Loctite (plastic bonder - 2 part mix).
Let it set for a few minutes and it was solid. Please feel free to comment on this item if you have any further questions. Also check out my Youtube Channel on 3D Printing if you want: www.YouTube.com/PrintThatThing

author: smithpj45

description.text: This provides an improved mount for attaching the y-axis belt to the y-bed on MakerFarm i3v-series printers. One concern with the OEM mounting approach is getting a tight belt connection using zip ties around the end of the belt loops. Another concern is that wrapping the belt around the M3 screws could lead to backlash/ripple as the belt rocks on the belt teeth, or as the teeth compress during acceleration and then slack later. These components are added to the MakerFarm wood belt mount and serve as a clamp to attach the belt. The clamp plate is shaped with form fitting GT2 2mm belt teeth using linear extrude polygon data from Parametric Pulley, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627. Use of the shaped tooth pattern should provide a very secure method for attaching the belt. The M3x25mm bolt used by MakerFarm to attach the y-belt mount to the y-bed needs to lengthened to M3x35mm in order to accommodate the clamp. Detailed instructions are included in the openSCAD script. This is intended to serve as a complement to the x-axis belt mount provided at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790207.

See the openSCAD script for instructions on tailoring the clamp, sizing the belt, and installing the belt. These are structural components. My parts were printed with 3 perimeters, 3 solid top & bottom layers, and 80% infill using Simplify3D as the slicer. Clearance between the end of the M3x35mm bolt and the return path of the belt can be an issue. Use of a pulley on the Y-idler bearings is recommended to increase the clearance - see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790138 for a suitable pulley. If belt clearance is an issue as the y-bed approaches the y-motor, a freestanding or freewheeling idler pulley can also be added between the belt near the y-motor.

author: raidokaldma

description.text:
Do you own a cell phone?
Do you have to recharge it using a wall socket? If the answer to both questions was YES then... WHERE do you put the cell phone and cord when you are charging it? The Parametric Cell Phone Charger Holder is the answer to this question!

A couple of STL files have been provided for printing but the real power in this thing is that it is fully parametric. You will need OpenSCAD (http://openscad.org) if you want to create a customized version but it is very easy to use. Just download the compressed archive and place it into an appropriate directory and start the executable. Any property of the Cell Phone Charger Holder is at the top of the source file. Simply change the value and press F5 to display the changes. If you have what you want press F2 to SAVE the file and F6 to compile it. Now you can export it to STL format and print it. For the SIMPLE version simply set the holder phone seperator (hps) to 0 and also height below (hb) to 0. Otherwise change the values for the other variables as desired such as holder width (hw), holder height (hh), phone height (ph) or phone width (pw). There is a mode variable "print" that you can set to 0 to display the cell phone charger holder as it will be used, otherwise use mode 1, 2 or 3 to print the phone part, cord part or both respectively.

This is another design of a fish feeder powered by arduino. The arduino uno is a separate unit from the feeder. All you need:
  • servo
  • arduino
    • No bearings required Print without supports at 10% infill
    PLA:
    Extruder temp at 200C and bed temp at 60C

Arduino code:
// Speedy Auto Feeder v4 on v6 firmware

int flag = 0;
Servo myservo; // create servo object to control a servo
int pos = 0; // variable to store the servo position void setup()
{
myservo.attach(9); // attaches the servo on pin 9 to the servo object
myservo.write(0); // tell servo to go to position in variable 'pos'
} void loop(){
// 1
myservo.write(180); // tell servo to go to position in variable 'pos'
delay(1000);
myservo.write(0);
delay(172800000); // Wait 2 days or 172800000 ms
//delay(5000); // Wait 5000 ms // 2
myservo.write(180); // tell servo to go to position in variable 'pos'
delay(1000);
myservo.write(0);
delay(172800000); // Wait 2 days or 172800000 ms
//delay(5000); // Wait 5000 ms // 3
myservo.write(180); // tell servo to go to position in variable 'pos'
delay(1000);
myservo.write(0);
delay(172800000); // Wait 2 days or 172800000 ms
//delay(5000); // Wait 5000 ms // 4
myservo.write(180); // tell servo to go to position in variable 'pos'
delay(1000);
myservo.write(0);
delay(86400000); // Wait 1 days or 86400000 ms
//delay(5000); // Wait 5000 ms
}

description.text:
I needed a connector to attach a 200W Meanwell driver to my printer, required for the heatbed as the heatbed (reprap mk3) isn't a standard thing but custom addon, meaning there aren't any holes provided in the bottom plate. Because i was reluctant to drill new holes in the bottom plate, I found a use for the otherwise useless (?) triangle shaped hole. As the surface is quite large I experimented with the piece by adding the vertex logo and my name on the top of the piece, printed upside down to provide a good surface for the brim.  
Added a version without the name fo everyone to print.
Printed with Red Velleman PLA Heatbed 50°C (first print was with buildtak without heatbed, but failed). Hot-end 190°C.

title: parametric plastic drawer joints to replacement  + bolt front of drawer in.

description.text:
I replaced and repaired my sons drawer with 4 plastic joints that i designed in open scad. these joints are strong enough for any furniture project as well. they hold wooden pieces together at 90deg angles. the joints are re enforced on the outside to increase strength.
My son likes to pull down on the drawer we have in his room. he broke the old 90deg joints, and this was a perfect opportunity to demonstrate 3d printing to my wife and save a few bucks.
it took all but 5 minutes to create parts in open scad, and 30 minutes after that i was replacing the old drawer joints with the new ones.

print out 4 of them, then use screws to join your projects together. need smaller or larger joints, or larger holes? no problem open scad file is included to make parametric changes
this saved me 5$ in gas to hardware store, and 3$ in parts.

Another option for storing smaller quantities of screws is a customized version of the compartment case. If you're in the US and need metric or stainless steel hardware, Trimcraft Aviation RC has the best prices I've seen and they have a good selection is sizes useful for 3D printers. Shipping is only $3. BoltDepot is a good option for sizes not available at Trimcraft. You can order in any quantity, but they're usually more expensive. title: Yazzo L Socket Locking Clip Supported

description.text: This very 'old' design has been enhanced to provide some support for the clip. The difference is a rounded cutout on the 'outside' of where the panels come together. It provides some stiffening to help prevent any flexing the panels might want to do at that point. The basic function of the clip is to bring panels together, without using any screws. The panels found on MakerBot and Ultimaker builds are typical of a 't-slot' screw and nut design. I have used this design to reconstruct my CupCake as documented here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5219

1) Print a few of these out
2) Snap them into places where you'd normally use the screw/nut combo
3) Rejoice! This clip is not strictly a replacement for a single screw as it requires a different configuration of the panels (no extended tabs). So, realistically, you need to replace all the screws, and make sure your panels have no tabs. This particular design is helpful for the bottom panel since it holds the power supply, it is heavy, and can use some support. There are other clips in the OpenScad file if you care to play around.

I printed with 5 perimeters, 200 microns, 50% infill with PLA. you'd probably be better off using ABS as it's less brittle, but it will just be another breaking point to save the motors if I crash hard again :)

• To print the left and right side, just duplicate and mirror

  • Drill out the hole in the boom

This is my first 3D object printed at UTAS for Digital Technologies ESH380.

As this was part of an assessment task for UTAS unit ESH380 Digital Technologies I have made it in to a lesson sequence for Year 7 students.  The main objective was to use Parametric Modelling software Autodesk Inventor Professional (free for students).  This software would transform the learning of skills and conceptual understanding only currently attained in Year 10 curriculum in Tasmania, Australia.  The final product is just a component of what would be taught and assessed.

Thanks to smutboy420 for updating my design. Check out his version for a cleaner and lighter design. He used PLA plastic instead of ABS. He used a bigger servo and updated the design to fit. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1307204 This is a design for a Multirotor parachute system.
Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d6k7jftG5uI For in depth build directions, see my article on the Flite Test web site Http://www.flitetest.com/articles/parachutes-are-cool-diy-multirotor-parachute

Parachute: spherachutes.com - I used a 36in parachute for the tests. I also built one using a 42 in parachute (used full tube for the 42in chute)
Tube: Pounce Cat Treat container (cut down for the 36in chute)
Spring: Homemade see link for directions. I used a 1 1/4in PVC Pipe
http://www.instructables.com/id/Make-your-own-springs-in-seconds/
Servo: 3.7g Turnigy servo (TGY-1370A)
Activation: I have my controller set up with two switches to activate parachute. Both switches need to be turned on. This prevents accidental deployment.

comments.author: AverageguyRC

comments.text:
Hopefully you dont mind that I did a lot of modifications to all 3 parts to this design t take the weight down on some of the parts that are to chunky and over built for the strength they need to be.
First was the spring plate disk. That was way thicker then it needed to be and I also added a bunch of holes in it so it now looks more like a small shower drain. I also made the top lid thinner and changed the hinge part was real long and blocky and not really needed So I shorted them up some to off more unneeded weight still. and after I tried a test print in abs on the ring part that goes around the cat treat tube. That I printed to thin and it broke while trying to pry it off my bed gave me the idea that that part was also almost 2 times as high as it needed to be to be able to hold the tube securely and was a lot more un needed weight that could be eliminated by tweaking the design to make that band almost 1/2 its with. Printing the 3 orignal parts in PLA seemed to be the best for these and the first run with the unmodified parts weighed in at 29.1 Grams with out the treat tube and all the other parts that need to be added to make the full launch system. But the modified parts all 3 of them now come in at just 17grams which is about a 40% reduction in weight on them parts.
comments.author: smutboy420

comments.text: If you feel like sharing your updated design on thingiverse, I'd be happy to add a link in my description over to your design so people could download your version. I'd be interested in seeing it as well.
comments.author: smutboy420

comments.text: here you go "DIY Multirotor Parachute System redesign" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1307204
comments.author: AverageguyRC

comments.text: That is outstanding.  I originally designed this for use with my xyz davinci 1.0 which is a fairly cheap printer. All I had was abs to print with.  Additionally I was printing at lower density. For example the spring plate was only done at 15%.  The higher stress components were printed at higher density. I didn't have a lot of experience printing or designing when I did this project. My intention was to eventually come back to try and reduce the mass of the printed components and tube.  I also wanted to try PLA as well. Thanks for the improvements.
comments.author: smutboy420

comments.text: I also printed mine on a davinci 1.0A  When I tried going with a low print density on the abs it was not working out to well esp when I tried the thinner versions. But the ones I did in PLA even at 5% were strong and the layers were all holding nice. Even with the trimmed down versions in the pla and low fill seemed to be the best strength to weight wise.   I still want to do some more tweeking of them and will up load the final ones that work out the best.   I also would like to find some lighter tubeing.
comments.author: AverageguyRC

description.text:
Make: Millions of Make robots with a hot glue injection mold! with the time of making these cute mascots lowered, now you can make more than ever before! The two mold pieces print in about 1 hour and 45 minutes total, and then you can start producing like mad! Post makes! I'd love to see how different layer heights and printer settings effect your millions of clones! Printed on a Printrbot Simple.
PLA from http://www.makerfront.com

printed at 0.3 layerheight, but any layerheight will work.
designed in 123d design STEPS FOR INJECTION
1.spray mold with cooking oil
2.set hot glue gun to low settings and let it heat
3.clamp the mold
4.place a layered piece of tin foil in the injection slot, so the mold doesn't melt.
5.inject the hot glue until it starts to leak out the air release slot (which is on the side)
6.wait 20-40 min for the mold to cool.
7.pull off the front of the mold.
8.carefully push out the leg with your fingernail and lift the model out of the mold
9.enjoy!
